page.title: 02Principal Features
page.content: Lodge Moor Hospital dominates the north_eastern corner of the block, with buildings and grounds covering an area of half a square kilometre. Originally a fever hospital built in the nineteenth century, it still operates under the aegis of the Trent Health Authority and provides employment for over 300 people. Lately it has become a specialist unit for treatment of spinal injuries, on a par with, though not as widely known as Stoke Mandeville Hospital. Its helicopter pad is regularly utilised to transport chronically ill patients. The land gradually rises to the north and west until it dramatically falls away into Rivelin Valley, occupied by the River Rivelin and the Redmires Dams, built between 1850 and 1870 to provide drinking water for the fast-expanding steel city of Sheffeild
